article.title: A Tissue Retrieval and Postharvest Processing Regimen for Rodent Reproductive Tissues Compatible with Long-Term Storage on the International Space Station and Postflight Biospecimen Sharing Program
article.abstract: Collection and processing of tissues to preserve space flight effects from animals after return to Earth is challenging.

sections.introduction: With the current paucity of opportunities for studying whole animal mammalian physiology in space flight, the Biospecimen Sharing Program (BSP) for postflight tissue collection offers the opportunity to broaden access to biological samples shortly after return and maximize the data generated from flight animal payloads.
sections.methods: Approximately 8 wk old male and female C57Bl/6J (Jackson Lab, Bar Harbor, ME) and ~10-month old male and female Mongolian gerbils (Charles River, Wilmington, MA) were used throughout this study.
sections.results: Testes harvested any time between time 0 after euthanasia up to 2.5â€‰hr after euthanasia showed histological properties comparable to the time 0-harvested mice.
sections.discussion: We report here a logical method to determine the optimal time window of tissue harvest and fixation after euthanasia for use in multi-investigator tissue harvest programs that is compatible with processing of tissue sample obtained from space flight animals.

article.insights_summary: We report a logical method to determine the optimal time window of tissue harvest and fixation after euthanasia for use in multi-investigator tissue harvest programs that is compatible with processing of tissue sample obtained from space flight animals.
article.acknowledgments: This study is supported by NASA Grant NNX09AP04G to Joseph S. Tash.
